ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc39:1.1_0: At one time when the Buddha was staying at Sāvatthī in Anāthapiṇḍika’s Monastery,
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc39:1.2_0: At that time the monks from the group of six ate fine foods that they themselves had asked for.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc39:1.3_0: People complained and criticized the monks,
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc39:1.4_0: “How can the Sakyan ascetics eat fine foods that they themselves have asked for?
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc39:1.5_0: Who doesn’t like nice food? Who doesn’t prefer tasty food?”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc39:1.6_0: The monks heard the complaints of those people
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc39:1.7_0: The monks of few desires complained and criticized Udāyī,
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc39:1.8_0: “How can the monks from the group of six do this?” ...
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc39:1.9_0: “Is it true, monks, that you do this?”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc39:1.12_0: “... Foolish men, how can you do this?
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc39:1.13_0: This won’t give rise to confidence in those without it ...” ...
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc39:1.14_0: “And, monks, this training rule should be recited like this:
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc39:1.15.1_0: “And these kinds of fine foods—that is, ghee, butter, oil, honey, molasses, and syrup—
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc39:1.15.1_1: If a monk eats fine foods that he himself has asked for, he commits an offense entailing confession.’”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc39:1.16_0: In this way the Buddha laid down this training rule for the monks.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc39:2.1_0: At one time a number of monks were sick.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc39:2.2_0: The monks who were looking after them asked,
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc39:2.3_0: “We hope you’re bearing up, we hope you’re comfortable?”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc39:2.4_0: “Previously we ate fine foods that we ourselves had asked for, and then we were comfortable.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc39:2.5_0: But now that the Buddha has prohibited this, we don’t ask because we’re afraid of wrongdoing. And because of that we’re not comfortable.”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc39:2.7_0: After giving a teaching, the Buddha addressed the monks:
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc39:2.8_0: “Monks, I allow a sick monk to eat fine foods that he himself has asked for.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc39:2.9_0: “And, monks, this training rule should be recited like this:
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc39:2.10.1_0: “And these kinds of fine foods—that is, ghee, butter, oil, honey, molasses, and syrup—
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc39:2.10.1_1: If a monk who is not sick eats fine foods that he himself has asked for, he commits an offense entailing confession.’”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc39:3.1.3_0: milk from cows, milk from goats, milk from buffaloes, or meat. And the ghee or oil.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc39:3.1.7_0: sesame oil, mustard-seed oil, honey-tree oil, castor oil, oil from fat.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc39:3.1.13_0: what lives in water is what is meant.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc39:3.1.15_0: the meat of those animals whose meat is allowable.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc39:3.1.17_0: milk from cows, milk from goats, milk from buffaloes, or milk from whatever animal whose meat is allowable.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc39:3.1.23_0: ...The monk who has been given the full ordination by a unanimous Sangha through a legal procedure consisting of one motion and three announcements that is irreversible and fit to stand—this sort of monk is meant in this case.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc39:3.1.24_0: Any of these kinds of fine foods:
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc39:3.1.27_0: who is comfortable without fine foods.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc39:3.1.29_0: who is not comfortable without fine foods.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc39:3.1.30_0: If he is not sick and he asks for himself, then for the effort there is an act of wrong conduct.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc39:3.1.31_0: When he receives it with the intention of eating it, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc39:3.1.32_0: For every mouthful, he commits an offense entailing confession.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc39:3.2.1_0: If he is not sick, and he does not perceive himself as sick, and he eats fine foods that he himself has asked for, he commits an offense entailing confession.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc39:3.2.2_0: If he is not sick, but he is unsure of it, and he eats fine foods that he himself has asked for, he commits an offense entailing confession.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc39:3.2.3_0: If he is not sick, but he perceives himself as sick, and he eats fine foods that he himself has asked for, he commits an offense entailing confession.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc39:3.2.4_0: If he is sick, but he perceives himself as not sick, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc39:3.2.5_0: If he is sick, but he is unsure of it, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc39:3.2.6_0: If he is sick, and he perceives himself as sick, there is no offense.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc39:3.3.1_0: there is no offense for him.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc39:3.3.3_0: if he asked for it when he was sick, but eats it when he is no longer sick;
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc39:3.3.4_0: if he eats the leftovers from one who is sick;
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc39:3.3.7_0: if it is built for someone else;
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc39:3.3.8_0: if it is by means of her own property;
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc39:3.3.10_0: if he is the first offender.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc39:3.3.11_0: The ninth rule, the training rule on fine foods, is finished.
